Quoddy Head State Park
Word after "open" in an Ali Baba command + term for a wide street like L.A.'s world-famous Sunset
Army rank immediately above private 1st class + hopping marsupial of the family Macropodidae
A new team to make 2 towns shudder: city that's home to Faneuil Hall + the NATO phonetic alphabet word for "Y", pluralized
5-letter synonym for "person" + blows thrown with your south paw
Belonging to dictionary maker Mr. Webster + a game in which you might hear, "You sank my aircraft carrier!"

rounds.comments: (Alex: You have to name the prisons at work.)

clues.text: A memoir: "On Feb. 4, 2004... Larry drove me to the women's prison in Danbury, Connecticut"
By Stephen King: "The inmates made jokes about the chair... they called it Old Sparky, or the Big Juicy"
By Solzhenitsyn: "How do people get to this clandestine archipelago?" (Compulsorily via arrest is the answer)
"Dantes crossed the awful threshold and the door closed noisily behind him ...he was in prison"
"At last news arrived...that Raskolnikov shunned everybody and that in prison he was unpopular with the convicts"
5-word phrase for the good fortune of the sons of Erin
Double hyphenated term meaning easygoing
This product was introduced in 1964 with 4 different marbits, or marshmallow bits
Dirty Harry tells a punk he's got to ask himself this 4-word question
clues.response: "Do you feel lucky?" (or "Do I feel lucky?")

clues.text: "To take" this means to accept whatever's available, especially food
With the help of a shotgun blast, Tony Montana takes a dive in this 1983 film
In a 2015 film his estranged son unmasks, then impales him & says "Thank you" before Chewie gets off a few shots
At the end of "The Dark Knight", this character played by Aaron Eckhart dies in a fall
Sean Connery won an Oscar for this film, in which his character doesn't survive
It was shocking when this lead & Oscar winner died in "Kingsman: The Secret Service"
Specific area for a shape with a circular base that tapers to a point
A right-angled rectangular seat
The orb close at hand
Friction reducer for a symmetrical 3-dimensional shape
The emptiness within the quadrilateral with 2 parallel sides
Fittingly, you speak of "driving" this, the number of people viewing a website
When discussing image quality on your computer screen, you may hear "PPI", meaning these per square inch
This item that identifies a particular cell phone user now comes in nano size, about 12 x 9 millimeters
Requiring one thing you have, like an ATM card, & one you know, like a PIN, is called 2-factor this -ation, AKA 2FA
Also plotted by prisoners, it's a hack that lets you run an application your phone's maker hasn't approved
Illinois' most populous
Ireland's second-most populous
Southwest Texas county named for a man who died in San Antonio
Catty English county on the border of Wales
Ohio's most populous; Cleveland is there
"Truth or Consequences isn't a choice! & Los Alamos may be the bomb, but it's Roswell that ends well!"
"Sure, Ogden & Orem are nice, but I prefer Brigham City-- gee, I've really got to work on my trash-talking"
"I get no kick from Champaign! I'm not Havana a good time! I only play in Peoria!"
"I'm not Spokane for, & I ain't putting on the Ritzville! Everybody loves Raymond!"
"Stick Three Forks in it, it's done! & kiss our Butte, Bozeman!"
Wyatt Earp said that this dentist sometimes drank 3 quarts of whiskey in a day
Drunk for his 1865 inaugural as VP, he said, "I kiss this book in the face of my nation of the United States" & smooched a Bible
One legend about this Who drummer says that to slow their intake, he & Oliver Reed used a tortoise to pass the bottle
Bill Clinton said this blotto Russian president tried to hail a cab on a D.C. street clad only in underwear; he wanted pizza
In a 1935 letter from Key West he wrote, "I have drunk since I was fifteen and few things have given me more pleasure"

rounds.comments: (Alex: The letters "B-R" will exit a word and produce the correct response for you.)

clues.text: A sibling loses its "BR" & becomes this word meaning "additional" or "different"
Riding trousers get too big for "BR", making these annoying sensations
Dropping "BR" from a horse's harness gets this state of inactivity
The "BR" strolls away from a word for any prickly shrub to walk along as this easy gait
A word for the edge of a steep place jettisons its "BR" & becomes this slang word for publicity
In this 2005 novel Bella tells Edward, "I like the night. Without the dark, we'd never see the stars"
Book 24 in Sue Grafton's Kinsey Millhone series has just this letter as its title
Oscar-nominated, a 2015 film was based on this bestseller about Eilis, a young Irish immigrant in NYC in the 1950s
Among Amazon's 20 bestselling books of 2015 were, for the first item, 2 of these books that aren't meant to be read
"Petals on the Wind" was the first sequel to this V.C. Andrews novel

rounds.text: The two 20th century first ladies whose first name was Elizabeth
